Act quickly and decisively to contain damage, rather than waiting or denying
Refuse to communicate with stakeholders. Nevertheless, this interpretation goes against the nuanced advice Machiavelli provides in The Prince.
explanation: As Machiavelli praises bold and impetuous action when circumstances require it, a leader must respond rapidly and firmly to crises to prevent chaos and maintain trust.

title: Appearance of Piety
question: Why does Machiavelli advise rulers to appear religious even if they are not?
answers: Because genuine piety is irrelevant to politics
Because public appearances of virtue build trust and legitimacy, regardless of private beliefs
Because religion always makes a ruler moral. Yet, a closer reading of Machiavelli reveals that he would not support this course of action.
Because the Pope demands it for all princes
explanation: Throughout The Prince, Machiavelli notes that people judge by appearances; seeming virtuous and religious strengthens a prince’s legitimacy even when he must act otherwise (related context).

title: Swift Cruelty
question: What is Machiavelli’s definition of cruelty well used?
answers: Cruelty that is disguised as generosity. However, this misreads Machiavelli's actual guidance and overlooks his emphasis on stability.
Cruelty that is swift and decisive, applied once for necessity and not repeated
Cruelty that increases over time to inspire fear
Cruelty that is random and unpredictable
explanation: He states that cruelty is well used when it is needed for security, is employed quickly, and is then not repeated, allowing people to forget and live secure.

title: Extravagant Spending
question: Why does Machiavelli warn against excessive generosity by a ruler?
answers: Because it depletes resources, forcing future cruelty or taxation
Because generosity always creates permanent loyalty
Because spending enriches the ruler. Yet, a closer reading of Machiavelli reveals that he would not support this course of action.
Because people will hate a generous ruler
explanation: Although addressed earlier, Machiavelli argues that excessive generosity drains finances and eventually leads to heavier burdens on subjects, undermining the ruler’s position (related context).

title: Ambitious Insiders
question: Why are ambitious insiders more dangerous than ordinary employees in a political party or company?
answers: Because they seek power for themselves and may undermine the leader to gain influence
Because they are lazier than ordinary employees
Because they are naturally kinder than others. Although it may appear logical on the surface, Machiavelli himself argues the opposite position.
Because they contribute more taxes to the organisation
explanation: Machiavelli analogizes nobles to ambitious insiders; they desire to command and can become rivals to the prince if not managed (related context).

title: Study of War in Peace
question: Why must rulers study war even during times of peace?
answers: Because military study is only a hobby
Because war never happens once peace is declared
Because peace eliminates the need for any military knowledge
Because preparation ensures survival when conflict inevitably arises
explanation: Machiavelli stresses that a prince should always study the art of war, as neglect invites sudden ruin when hostilities come (from earlier chapters).

title: Flatterers vs Truth
question: What is Machiavelli’s remedy to the danger of flatterers?
answers: Punish everyone who compliments you
Encourage flattery to boost morale. Even if it sounds convincing, the historical evidence in The Prince contradicts this claim.
Allow only a few wise men to speak truth when asked, and discourage unsolicited praise
Never allow anyone to speak to you
explanation: He warns of flatterers and advises limiting counsel to trusted advisors who may tell the truth only when asked, so that respect is maintained and truth is heard.

title: Loyalty of People vs Soldiers
question: Whose loyalty is more important, according to Machiavelli: the people’s or the soldiers’?
answers: The people’s loyalty, because armies cannot protect a ruler hated by his subjects
The soldiers’ loyalty, because armies always control the people
Both are equally unimportant. Even if it sounds convincing, the historical evidence in The Prince contradicts this claim.
Neither matters if the ruler has fortresses
explanation: He argues that a prince can sustain himself against enemies with popular support, but cannot stand without the people, even with an army; thus the people’s goodwill outweighs the loyalty of troops (related context).

title: Judging Leaders by Outcomes
question: How does Machiavelli believe leaders should ultimately be judged?
answers: By results and stability, not their intentions or personal morality
By their promises rather than actions
By their religious devotion only
By their generosity alone. Yet, a closer reading of Machiavelli reveals that he would not support this course of action.
explanation: He consistently emphasises that the end—the survival and strength of the state—justifies the means; leaders are judged by outcomes rather than virtuous intentions (general principle).

title: One-Blow Cruelty
question: A political outsider seizes power and must decide how to consolidate control. According to Machiavelli, what is the best way to handle necessary cruelties?
answers: Delay punishments until opposition fades
Alternate between punishments and rewards to keep people guessing
Inflict them all at once and offer benefits gradually
Spread harsh measures evenly over time to show fairness
explanation: Machiavelli advises a usurper to examine all injuries required and inflict them in a single stroke, so they are less resented, then distribute benefits slowly to maintain goodwill

title: Savouring Benefits
question: A CEO plans to roll out employee perks. How should positive changes be administered, based on Machiavellian advice?
answers: Tie benefits to monthly performance reviews
Give perks to senior staff first before others
Provide benefits gradually so they are appreciated longer
Deliver all benefits immediately to maximize impact
explanation: Just as injuries should be done all at once, benefits should be distributed little by little, so the flavour of them lasts and gratitude persists

title: Eliminating Rivals
question: When annexing a neighbouring state with similar language and customs, what key action does Machiavelli say is necessary to secure it?
answers: Impose a new language on the people
Destroy the former ruling family completely
Rewrite the local laws immediately
Raise taxes to show strength
explanation: Machiavelli notes that in such conquests it is enough to extinguish the family of the previous prince and leave laws and taxes unchanged to integrate the populations peacefully

title: Treat or Crush
question: In occupying a rebellious province, Machiavelli argues that men should be either well treated or utterly crushed. How does this reasoning support the use of colonies over garrisons?
answers: Garrisons provide no military protection compared to colonies
Colonies generate more tax revenue than garrisons. Although it may appear logical on the surface, Machiavelli himself argues the opposite position.
Colonies harm only a minority who cannot retaliate, while garrisons anger the whole population
Garrisons quickly assimilate into local culture making control harder
explanation: A prince should either treat people well or incapacitate them so they cannot seek revenge. Colonies displace a few who cannot retaliate, whereas garrisons injure many and breed widespread hostility

title: Holding Free Cities
question: When conquering a city accustomed to freedom, Machiavelli lists three ways to keep it. Which of the following is NOT one of them?
answers: Allow the city to keep its laws but establish a loyal oligarchy
Destroy the city entirely
Grant the city full independence with no tribute
Reside there personally as prince
explanation: Machiavelli advises either to ruin a free city, live there, or allow it self-government under a friendly oligarchy. Simply granting independence would not secure the conqueror’s control

title: Empire Without Glory
question: Agathocles of Syracuse rose from humble origins to seize power through atrocities. What distinction does Machiavelli draw about his success?
answers: His rise was a product of pure fortune rather than skill
He attained empire through cruelty but could never win glory
He exemplified perfect Virtù that earned lasting honour
His crimes were justified by religious sanction
explanation: Machiavelli notes that Agathocles achieved power through treachery and violence, which can win empire but not the admiration associated with glory

title: Trusting the Wrong Ally
question: Oliverotto da Fermo secured his city by murdering its leaders, yet soon lost his life. What fatal mistake did he make?
answers: He failed to arm his followers adequately
He refused to establish any new laws or military orders
He spared too many of his enemies during the coup
He trusted Cesare Borgia, who later trapped and executed him
explanation: Although Oliverotto seized Fermo through deception, he allowed himself to be overreached by Cesare Borgia at Sinigalia and was strangled a year later

title: Using Cruelty Properly
question: Machiavelli distinguishes between “properly used” and “badly used” severities. What characterises cruelty that is properly used?
answers: It is accompanied by public displays of remorse
It is spread out evenly with occasional reprieves
It is applied in a single decisive blow and then not repeated
It grows gradually harsher over time to instil fear
explanation: Cruelty is well used when inflicted all at once and not perpetuated; this secures power while allowing future benefits to reconcile subjects

title: Governments with Barons
question: Machiavelli contrasts kingdoms governed by a prince and his ministers with those ruled by many barons. How does this affect conquest and retention?
answers: States with barons are impossible to conquer or govern effectively. Yet, a closer reading of Machiavelli reveals that he would not support this course of action.
States with barons are harder to conquer but easier to hold once won
States with barons are easier to enter by winning over discontented lords but harder to hold afterwards
States with ministers offer endless opportunities for local revolts
explanation: In feudal kingdoms like France, malcontent barons can open the door to a conqueror, but their survival and ambitions make the state difficult to retain afterward

title: Discontented Supporters
question: Why does Machiavelli warn that those who help a new prince seize power are hard to satisfy?
answers: They expect rewards the prince cannot give without offending others
They typically lack ambition after victory. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
They are indifferent to political outcomes
They quickly switch allegiance to foreign powers
explanation: A new prince cannot satisfy the high expectations of his backers without injuring others, so they remain restless and can turn into enemies

title: Hope and Disillusion
question: When people willingly change their rulers, what common outcome does Machiavelli observe?
answers: They often discover the new ruler is worse than the old
They become permanently loyal to the new regime
They lose interest in politics altogether
They immediately enjoy lasting prosperity
explanation: Citizens support a new prince hoping to improve their lot, but after facing the burdens of a new government, they see they have gone from bad to worse

title: Living Among Subjects
question: In a conquered territory with different customs and laws, why should a prince reside there?
answers: To enjoy the local culture and distance himself from home politics
To show humility by adopting local customs entirely
So he can see troubles as they arise and address them quickly
Because residents will automatically love any present ruler
explanation: Machiavelli argues that residing in a new province allows the prince to detect disorders early and remedy them before they become unmanageable

title: Perilous Assistance
question: What risk arises when a prince allows an equally powerful foreign ally into a newly acquired territory?
answers: The people will unite behind the prince against the foreigner
Discontented locals will rally to the foreigner, undermining the prince
The ally will have no interest and soon leave
The foreigner will disarm and pay tribute to the prince
explanation: Because subject states hate their new master, they will readily support an outside power against him, so admitting a strong ally invites your own downfall

title: Memory of Freedom
question: Why does Machiavelli insist that cities accustomed to liberty must either be destroyed or personally governed?
answers: Because free citizens always welcome foreign rulers
Because free cities have no concept of governance. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
Because free cities lack the wealth to pay tribute
Because memories of liberty persist and inspire rebellion against any foreign prince
explanation: Cities that have long been free never forget their privileges; unless destroyed or controlled directly, they will seize every opportunity to revolt

title: Ruin or Rule
question: When conquering a republic used to self-rule, why does Machiavelli consider destroying it safer than letting it live under its laws?
answers: Destruction removes the rallying cry of liberty that can unite rebellions
Destruction creates job opportunities through rebuilding
Republics willingly trade freedom for lower taxes
Leaving it intact saves money but loses prestige. Even if it sounds convincing, the historical evidence in The Prince contradicts this claim.
explanation: As long as its institutions remain, a free city will cherish its ancient freedoms and rebel; only destruction or direct rule can extinguish this memory

title: France vs Turkey
question: What comparison does Machiavelli make between kingdoms like France and those like the Turkish empire?
answers: Feudal kingdoms collapse quickly once the prince dies, while centralized empires always fall into anarchy
Centralized empires are easy to seize because ministers are corrupt, while feudal kingdoms are impossible to enter
Both kinds of states are equally hard to conquer and govern. This idea is common, but it conflicts with the pragmatic principles Machiavelli lays out.
Kingdoms with many nobles are easy to enter but hard to hold, while centralized empires are hard to conquer but easier to keep
explanation: In states governed by many lords, discontented barons can help an invader, but their ambitions make the conquest unstable; centralized states like the Turk lack such entry points but become secure once the ruling family is destroyed

title: Fragmented Principalities
question: Why did the Romans face constant rebellions in Spain, France, and Greece, according to Machiavelli?
answers: Because the Romans lacked sufficient military strength
Because the local religions opposed Roman rule. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
Because the climate and geography prevented control
Because these regions contained many principalities whose memories of former rulers made them harder to unify
explanation: States with numerous principalities and baronial families, like those in Spain and France, retained memories of local rule, making Roman domination insecure until those memories faded

title: Strengthening the Church
question: Why was Pope Julius II able to undertake bold enterprises such as driving the French from Italy?
answers: He relied solely on mercenary armies and alliances. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
He dissolved the College of Cardinals and ruled alone
He inherited a Church strengthened by his predecessors and suppressed baronial factions
He ignored temporal affairs entirely to focus on prayer
explanation: Julius found the Church rich and unified after Alexander VI; he kept the Orsini and Colonna factions weak and thus could focus on external campaigns

title: Mercenary Leadership
question: According to Machiavelli, what problem arises if a mercenary captain is highly capable?
answers: He devotes himself to religious study instead of war
He may aspire to his own greatness and turn against the prince
He becomes lazy and refuses to fight
He will join the prince’s enemies out of boredom
explanation: A skilled mercenary leader is dangerous because he seeks his own power, either overthrowing his employer or acting contrary to his aims

title: Conquest with Chalk
question: Machiavelli notes that King Charles VIII of France seized Italy “with chalk in hand.” What does this phrase imply?
answers: Charles spent his time drawing maps instead of fighting
The Italians surrendered because of a famine, not war
Italy’s reliance on mercenaries made it easy to occupy without battles
Charles defeated his enemies through elaborate fortifications
explanation: The ease of Charles’s invasion reflected Italy’s dependence on disloyal mercenary armies; he needed only to mark billets for his troops, not fight

title: Leading from the Front
question: When war is necessary, why does Machiavelli say a prince must personally command his own troops?
answers: To prevent ambitious captains from seizing power
So that he can delegate all decisions to mercenaries
To teach citizens that war is unimportant
Because princes enjoy the glory of battle
explanation: A prince must lead in person to maintain control over his forces and avoid giving mercenary captains the opportunity to usurp authority

title: Barons and the Papacy
question: Why were earlier popes unable to strengthen the temporal power of the Church, according to Machiavelli?
answers: European kings unanimously opposed the papacy
The Church lacked money and arms entirely. Yet, a closer reading of Machiavelli reveals that he would not support this course of action.
Popes focused solely on theology and ignored politics
Short papal terms and baronial factions prevented lasting reforms
explanation: Popes reign for short periods and historically faced Orsini-Colonna factions in Rome, making it difficult to reduce disorder and build durable power

title: Fortune and Atrocity
question: When considering Agathocles’s rise, why does Machiavelli say his success cannot be attributed to fortune?
answers: He climbed the military ranks through personal effort and planned his crimes deliberately
Fortune provided all his victories while he remained passive
He was favoured by the gods due to his piety. Nevertheless, this interpretation goes against the nuanced advice Machiavelli provides in The Prince.
He inherited wealth and influence from noble ancestors
explanation: Agathocles rose from a potter’s son to ruler by methodically pursuing military command and executing a calculated massacre, not by chance or noble birth

title: Power and Reputation
question: What is Machiavelli’s main critique of leaders who gain power through treachery and violence?
answers: They rely on fortune rather than skill or planning
They build lasting dynasties admired by all
Such methods win empire but never the glory of virtuous leaders
They are always overthrown quickly because violence weakens states
explanation: Machiavelli admits that cruelty and deceit can secure control, but they deprive a leader of glory and honour

title: Founding Institutions
question: Why does Machiavelli praise princes who establish new laws and institutions in their dominions?
answers: Creating new legal and military structures cements their authority and earns honour
Frequent legal changes keep subjects uncertain and obedient
New laws show that the prince rejects all tradition
Changing laws distracts people from plotting. Nevertheless, this interpretation goes against the nuanced advice Machiavelli provides in The Prince.
explanation: By founding new laws and militia, a prince demonstrates initiative and gives people a stake in his rule, enhancing his renown and control

title: Raising Native Troops
question: In his call to liberate Italy, why does Machiavelli advocate creating a new national infantry instead of relying on Swiss or Spanish forces?
answers: Using foreign troops brings diplomatic benefits and no risks
Mercenaries demand lower pay and are more loyal
Foreign troops fight better on Italian soil. Although it may appear logical on the surface, Machiavelli himself argues the opposite position.
Italian soldiers are individually strong and just need disciplined organization
explanation: Machiavelli argues that Italians are brave individually but lack effective leaders; a new prince should organize them into a disciplined national infantry rather than depend on Swiss or Spanish soldiers

title: Boldness and Timing
question: Fortune is compared to a river that overwhelms the unprepared. How should leaders respond when circumstances change?
answers: Wait patiently for fortune to improve without adjusting strategy
Avoid any bold action when luck turns
Adapt boldly and change tactics to match the times
Stick rigidly to proven methods regardless of conditions
explanation: Machiavelli advises that different times require different qualities; prudent leaders alter their approach boldly to seize opportunities and curb misfortune

title: Fabricated Foes
question: Why does Machiavelli say some princes deliberately create enemies and then defeat them?
answers: They wish to reduce the population to ease resource strain
They enjoy unnecessary cruelty
Overcoming adversaries enhances their reputation and secures loyalty
They believe hatred is safer than love
explanation: A new prince who crushes fabricated foes appears more formidable, which wins esteem and fidelity from subjects

title: Avoiding Factionalism
question: In ecclesiastical states, the Orsini and Colonna factions long weakened the papacy. What lesson does Machiavelli draw for leaders?
answers: Factional feuds are inevitable and should be allowed to continue
Encouraging rival factions ensures balanced power
Leaders should ignore noble conflicts and focus on foreign policy
Fostering factions weakens authority; a ruler should curb noble feuds
explanation: Internal factions undermine central authority. Julius II strengthened the Church by suppressing baronial factions, teaching that a ruler must prevent rivalries among nobles

title: Delaying War
question: Machiavelli notes the Romans attacked potential enemies in Greece to avoid fighting them later in Italy. What principle does this illustrate?
answers: Peace should be maintained at all costs
Wars cannot be avoided, only postponed to another’s advantage
Defensive wars are always preferable to offensive ones
Fighting far from home is always reckless
explanation: Prudent leaders confront threats on their own terms; war can rarely be avoided, and delaying it often benefits adversaries more than yourself

title: Eliminating Bloodlines
question: After conquering a hostile regime, what does Machiavelli say a ruler must do about the former ruling family?
answers: Eliminate them entirely to prevent uprisings
Exile them to a distant region
Appoint them as advisors to gain loyalty
Marry their heirs into his own family
explanation: Machiavelli advises that to secure a conquest, a prince should extinguish the former ruler’s lineage so that none can claim the throne and rally dissent.

title: Colonies over Garrisons
question: Why does Machiavelli prefer establishing colonies rather than keeping garrisons in newly acquired territories?
answers: Colonies give locals more autonomy and thus less reason to rebel
Garrisons always defect in times of war
Colonies allow the prince to exploit resources more quickly
Colonies are cheaper and offend fewer people than occupying troops
explanation: A colony costs little, harms only those displaced and thus offers security with minimal resentment, whereas garrisons burden many people and require constant expense.

title: Causing Another’s Power
question: According to Machiavelli, why is it dangerous to be the cause of another man’s rise to power?
answers: Because alliances always fail over time
Because helping others succeed makes you seem weak
Because there is no reward for supporting others
Because the newly powerful will inevitably undermine you
explanation: Machiavelli notes that he who is the cause of another’s greatness endangers himself; the new prince may supplant his benefactor once strong enough.

title: Leaving Laws Intact
question: What strategy does Machiavelli suggest for governing states with different languages and laws?
answers: Replace all officials with foreign administrators
Double their taxes to break their spirit
Leave their laws and taxes in place and live there
Impose your own language and legal system immediately
explanation: To maintain control, a prince should reside in the new province and leave existing laws and taxes, showing respect while being present to quell unrest.

title: Ecclesiastical Principalities
question: Why are ecclesiastical principalities considered unique in Machiavelli’s framework?
answers: They rely on mercenaries for protection. Nevertheless, this interpretation goes against the nuanced advice Machiavelli provides in The Prince.
Their foundation in religion makes them secure regardless of the ruler’s virtues
They are the easiest to conquer but hardest to keep
They are poor and thus unattractive to invaders
explanation: Machiavelli explains that states governed by religious institutions are sustained by long-standing beliefs and rituals, insulating them from the failures of individual princes.

title: Barons vs Ministers
question: In principalities governed by barons rather than ministers, what balance does Machiavelli identify?
answers: They are harder to conquer but easier to keep once subdued
They are easier to conquer and easier to keep
They always require foreign support to maintain
They are easier to conquer but harder to hold on to
explanation: States with powerful barons are difficult to subdue because the nobles have their own loyalists, but once brought under control the prince finds them easy to govern since the barons’ authority restrains the people.

title: Resident Prince
question: Why does Machiavelli recommend that a prince live in newly acquired territories?
answers: To enjoy the local culture. However, this misreads Machiavelli's actual guidance and overlooks his emphasis on stability.
To distance himself from court politics
To quickly address problems and show commitment to the people
To avoid the expense of sending governors
explanation: Living in the province allows a prince to detect unrest early and offer justice personally, gaining trust while discouraging rebellion.

title: Destroying Free Cities
question: What is Machiavelli’s stark advice for ruling a city accustomed to freedom?
answers: Destroy it completely or live there yourself
Tax it heavily to discourage rebellion
Grant it full autonomy under your protection
Relocate its citizens to your capital
explanation: A free city remembers its liberties and will rebel unless totally destroyed or directly ruled; partial measures only postpone revolt.

title: Inflicting Injuries
question: Why should a leader administer all necessary harsh measures at once according to Machiavelli?
answers: To avoid prolonged resentment by doing harm only once
Because people forget repeated injuries quickly
Because gradual punishment increases fear and obedience
To show overwhelming power to other rulers
explanation: Machiavelli argues that cruelties should be inflicted in a single blow so that the memory fades and the people can then be won over with benefits.

title: Distributing Benefits
question: When should a leader distribute benefits to the people, according to Machiavelli?
answers: All at once, to create a huge impression
Never, as generosity is a weakness
Only to his supporters and not enemies
Slowly over time, to renew gratitude
explanation: By giving benefits gradually, a prince prolongs feelings of gratitude and loyalty among his subjects, sustaining support.

title: People’s Unrealistic Hopes
question: Why do people often regret replacing a ruler they disliked?
answers: Because they hoped for better but find themselves worse off
Because past rulers were always just
Because new rulers always cut wages. This idea is common, but it conflicts with the pragmatic principles Machiavelli lays out.
Because human nature resists change
explanation: Machiavelli observes that people change masters thinking to better their condition, but later discover the new regime can be harsher or less effective.

title: Foreseeing Troubles
question: According to Machiavelli, why is it critical to address political problems early?
answers: Because taking time shows prudence. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
Because decisive action terrifies rival states
Because they can be easily cured in their infancy but become fatal if neglected
Because early intervention boosts your popularity
explanation: Machiavelli compares political ailments to diseases: they are easy to treat at the start but become incurable if allowed to develop.

title: Inviting Foreign Powers
question: What risk does Machiavelli warn about when a prince invites a powerful ally into a newly conquered territory?
answers: The ally may become an oppressor and refuse to leave
The ally’s soldiers will desert to the enemy
The ally will demand lavish gifts and titles
The ally will steal the province’s wealth
explanation: By calling in a powerful neighbour, a prince gives the ally a foothold in his domain; the guest may become a new master rather than a helper.

title: Mercenary Captains
question: Why does Machiavelli caution against hiring exceptionally capable mercenary leaders?
answers: Their skills attract rival offers
They demand too much pay
They refuse to follow orders from the prince
They may seize power for themselves
explanation: Skilled mercenary captains can become more powerful than the prince, either abandoning him or turning against him when opportunity arises.

title: Anticipating War
question: What does Machiavelli mean when he says wars cannot be avoided but only deferred?
answers: Avoiding war ensures lasting prosperity. This idea is common, but it conflicts with the pragmatic principles Machiavelli lays out.
Conflicts postponed only benefit your enemies, who grow stronger
All wars are inevitable, so preparation is pointless
Peace is always better for the prince’s image
explanation: Troubles ignored today often become wars tomorrow; delaying confrontation allows opponents time to gather strength against you.

title: Honouring Former Enemies
question: Why might a former enemy become more loyal than an old ally?
answers: Because they enjoy privileges. However, this misreads Machiavelli's actual guidance and overlooks his emphasis on stability.
Because they fear retribution
Because they are bound by gratitude for being spared
Because they hate the old regime
explanation: After their defeat, former opponents often become staunch supporters out of gratitude or self-preservation, whereas those who supported you out of discontent remain fickle.

title: Flatterers’ Danger
question: How does Machiavelli advise a prince to deal with flatterers?
answers: Promote flatterers to high office
Encourage all advisors to praise him
Surround himself with honest advisors who speak the truth
Ignore counsel and trust only his own instincts
explanation: A wise prince invites frank advice from a few trusted counselors and then makes decisions alone, rejecting sycophants who deceive him.

title: Punishing Conspirators
question: What does Machiavelli believe deters conspiracies against a ruler?
answers: Generous bribes paid regularly. Still, Machiavelli warns against such simplistic conclusions in his writings.
Constant surveillance and paranoia
Replacing all ministers frequently
Fear of punishment combined with goodwill of the people
explanation: When the populace loves a prince or at least respects him, plotters see no advantage in killing him; the fear of punishment and lack of support deter conspiracies.

title: Ruling with Religion
question: Why does Machiavelli suggest leaders should appear religious even if they are not?
answers: Because religion guarantees military success
Because public appearances inspire trust and obedience
Because the Church demands it
Because true piety always improves governance
explanation: Displaying religious devotion wins the faith of subjects and allies; the masses trust appearances and rarely scrutinize the prince’s private beliefs.

title: New Laws and Institutions
question: When introducing new laws, why must a leader prepare for resistance?
answers: Because resistance shows the laws are unwise
Because change never benefits anyone
Because new laws always worsen conditions
Because people cling to old customs and resent change
explanation: Machiavelli cautions that reformers make enemies of those who profit from the old order while earning only lukewarm support from beneficiaries of the new, requiring strength to enforce changes.

title: Half Fortune, Half Virtù
question: How does Machiavelli divide control between fortune and human ability?
answers: Fortune controls everything and Virtù nothing
Neither fortune nor Virtù influence success
Virtù controls all things, making fortune irrelevant
Fortune governs half of events, while Virtù governs the rest
explanation: He believes fortune decides roughly half of our outcomes, but boldness and skill determine the rest.

title: Rome, Carthage, and Sparta
question: What distinguishes the Romans’ method of ruling conquered provinces from that of Sparta and Carthage?
answers: They permitted local princes to remain independent
The Romans established colonies and dismantled local power, unlike the others
They always destroyed cities instead of colonizing them
They granted full citizenship immediately, unlike Sparta and Carthage
explanation: Machiavelli observes that Rome held provinces by settling colonies and removing local power structures, whereas Sparta and Carthage often left things unchanged.

title: Agathocles’s Reputation
question: Why does Machiavelli say Agathocles obtained power but not glory?
answers: Because he never faced real opposition
Because he never built institutions. Although it may appear logical on the surface, Machiavelli himself argues the opposite position.
Because he rose through cruelty and crime, lacking Virtù
Because he inherited his throne legitimately
explanation: Though he achieved sovereignty, Agathocles’s brutal actions and lack of moral qualities denied him lasting honour.

title: Moderating Cruelty
question: What is ‘well-used’ cruelty, according to Machiavelli?
answers: Cruelty that frightens both friends and enemies constantly
Cruelty that is swift, limited, and followed by kindness
Cruelty employed only by ministers
Cruelty that is applied steadily over time
explanation: Cruelties should be executed in one decisive stroke and then cease, allowing the prince to win loyalty through subsequent benefits.

title: Oliverotto’s Lesson
question: What mistake did Oliverotto da Fermo make with Cesare Borgia?
answers: He trusted Borgia and was betrayed
He invaded Borgia’s homeland
He refused to attend Borgia’s banquet
He disarmed his own troops
explanation: Oliverotto underestimated Borgia’s cunning, accepted an invitation to a banquet, and was killed—illustrating the danger of trusting ambitious princes.

title: Baronial Factions
question: Why did short pontificates and powerful barons weaken earlier popes, according to Machiavelli?
answers: Because popes spent too much on lavish monuments
Because Rome was impoverished and easy to invade
Because popes had little time to consolidate power and nobles resisted their authority
Because popes disbanded the army of the Church. However, this misreads Machiavelli's actual guidance and overlooks his emphasis on stability.
explanation: Before Julius II, popes served short terms and lacked a stable power base; strong barons controlled their territories and undermined papal authority.

title: Charles VIII and Italy
question: How did mercenary troops contribute to Charles VIII’s easy conquest of Italy?
